natural problem:
Is $f(x) = \log{x} $ an even function, odd function, or neither?

Enter "odd", "even", or "neither".
natural solution: We can try a few values to see if the function satisfies the properties. $f(1) = \log{1}$ and $f(-1) = \log (-1)$ which is not defined! Since to be even, $f(x) = f(-x)$ for all $x$ in the domain of $f$, $f$ is not even.
For the same reason, $f$ is not odd. The answer is $\boxed{\text{neither}}.$

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x > 0. f x = log x"
shows  "((\<forall> x > 0. f x = f (-x)) \<or> (\<forall> x > 0. f x = - f (-x)) \<or> (\<forall> x > 0. f x \<noteq> f (-x) \<and> f x \<noteq> -f (-x))) = Neither"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Is $f(x) = \log{x} $ an even function, odd function, or neither?

Enter "odd", "even", or "neither". The final Answer is \text{neither}
 ### Proof
 We can try a few values to see if the function satisfies the properties. $f(1) = \log{1}$ and $f(-1) = \log (-1)$ which is not defined! Since to be even, $f(x) = f(-x)$ for all $x$ in the domain of $f$, $f$ is not even.
 For the same reason, $f$ is not odd. The answer is $\boxed{\text{neither}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x > 0. f x = log x"
shows  "((\<forall> x > 0. f x = f (-x)) \<or> (\<forall> x > 0. f x = - f (-x)) \<or> (\<forall> x > 0. f x \<noteq> f (-x) \<and> f x \<noteq> -f (-x))) = Neither"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: For a function $f(x) = \log x$ for all positive $x$, establish which of the following conditions is true: $f(x) = f(-x)$, $f(x) = -f(-x)$, or neither of these equalities hold for all positive $x$. The final answer is "neither".
